case_name: Borough Municipality of Bhusawal v. Bhusawal Electricity Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 47 and 48 of 1961 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 47 and 48 of 1961. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 5, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 1085 of 1954 with second Appeal No. 1086 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 5, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 1085 of 1954 with second Appeal No. 1086 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 5, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 1085 of 1954 with second Appeal No. 1086 of 1954. S. Pathak and Naunit Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by MUDHOLKAR J. on December 10, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: December 10, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR J.-This judgment will also govern C.A. number 48 of 1961. Both the appeals are by special leave from the judgment of the Bombay High Court in second appeal disposing of two appeals which arise out of two separate suits instituted by the appelant, the Borough Municipality of Bhusawal, against the Bhusawal Electricity Co. Ltd., respondent No. 1 before us, to which suits the State of Bombay was later added as a defendant.

facts.text: Two separate suits instituted by the appellant, the Borough Municipality of Bhusawal, against the Bhusawal Electricity Co. Ltd., respondent No. 1, to which suits the State of Bombay was later added as a defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Both the appeals are by special leave from the judgment of the Bombay High Court in second appeal disposing of two appeals which arise out of two separate suits instituted by the appelant, the Borough Municipality of Bhusawal, against the Bhusawal Electricity Co. Ltd., respondent No. 1 before us, to which suits the State of Bombay was later added as a defendant. In each of the two suits the appellant had claimed refund of two sums of money paid by them to the respondent No. 1 under protest as electricity charges to which the respondent No. 1 claimed to be entitled by virtue of an order made by the Government of Bombay under the Bombay Electricity Supply  Licensed Undertakings War Costs  Order, 1944  herein referred as Surcharge Order  .

facts.text: Appellant claimed refund of two sums of money paid by them to respondent No. 1 under protest as electricity charges.

anchor.surface_text: In each of the two suits the appellant had claimed refund of two sums of money paid by them to the respondent No. 1 under protest as electricity charges to which the respondent No. 1 claimed to be entitled by virtue of an order made by the Government of Bombay under the Bombay Electricity Supply  Licensed Undertakings War Costs  Order, 1944  herein referred as Surcharge Order  . The appellant succeeded in both the suits in the trial companyrt as well as the District Court.

facts.text: Electricity charges claimed entitled by respondent No. 1 by virtue of an order made by the Government of Bombay under the Bombay Electricity Supply (Licensed Undertakings) War Costs Order, 1944 (Surcharge Order).

anchor.surface_text: to which the respondent No. 1 claimed to be entitled by virtue of an order made by the Government of Bombay under the Bombay Electricity Supply  Licensed Undertakings War Costs  Order, 1944  herein referred as Surcharge Order  . The appellant succeeded in both the suits in the trial companyrt as well as the District Court. In second appeal, however, the High Court set aside the decrees passed by the trial companyrt and dismissed the two suits.

facts.text: Appellant succeeded in both suits in the trial court as well as the District Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant succeeded in both the suits in the trial companyrt as well as the District Court. In second appeal, however, the High Court set aside the decrees passed by the trial companyrt and dismissed the two suits. XLI, r. 27, Code of Civil Procedure is inapplicable to a second appeal.

facts.text: Appellant not liable to pay the surcharge payable under the Surcharge Order, 1944 in respect of electrical energy consumed by it, based on interpretation of agreements.

anchor.surface_text: Basing itself on a particular interpretation of the agreements regarding payment of electric charges with respondent number 1, the appellant claimed refund on the ground that it was number liable to pay the surcharge payable under the Surcharge Order, 1944 in respect of electrical energy companysumed by it.

facts.text: Substantial defence of respondent No. 1: dispute between it and the municipality was decided by the Government of Bombay and under second proviso to cl. 5 of Surcharge Order, 1944, decision final and binding.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial defence of the respondent number 1 was that the dispute between it and the municipality was decided by the Government of Bombay and that under the second proviso to cl. 5 of the Surcharge Order, 1944 the decision of the Government was final and binding both on the appellant and the respondent No. 1.

facts.text: It is not disputed that the decision of the Government upon the dispute is final and binding on the parties.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed before us by Mr. Pathak that the decision of the Government upon the dispute is final and binding on the parties.

facts.text: Government communication Ex. 68 dated May 22, 1946 relied upon by respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: that a certain companymunication sent by the Government to the parties, Ex. 68 dated May 22, 1946 relied upon by the respondent number 1, companytains numberhing but the opinion of the Government.

facts.text: Government letter No. 6404/36-E11 dated 22nd May, 1946 from Secretary to Government of Bombay Public Works Department to President, Borough Municipality, Bhusawal, subject War Costs Surcharge.

anchor.surface_text: The companymunication of May 22, 1946 relied upon by the first respondent runs thus No. 6404/36-E1 1 . Public Works Department, Bombay Castel, 22nd May, 1946. From The Secretary to the Government of Bombay Public Works Department  Irrigation . TO The President, The Borough Municipality, Bhusawal. Subject War Costs Surcharge.

facts.text: Government decided that municipality should pay the surcharge to Bhusawal Electricity Co. Ltd. at the rate of 15% fixed in Government Order No. 6331/36 IV dated 15th August, 1944, unless the Company raised its rate of supply of energy for street lighting to more than 4 annas per unit.

anchor.surface_text: I am to inform you that Government has fully companysidered your case under the second proviso to clause 5 of the Bombay Electricity Supply  Licensed Undertakings War Costs  Order, 1944, and has decided that you should pay the surcharge to the Bhusawal Electricity Co. Ltd., at the rate of 15 fixed in Government Order No. 6331/36  IV  dated the 15th August, 1944, unless the Company raised its rate of supply of energy for street lighting to more than 4 annas per unit.

facts.text: Both parties stated their respective cases before the Government under the second proviso to cl. 5 of the Order of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious from this companymunication that both the parties, that is, the appellant as well as the respondent number 1 had stated their respective cases before the Government.

facts.text: No War Costs Surcharge effective upon charges for supply under contract entered after 1st May, 1942, unless provides same as previous contracts or decision of Provincial Government final in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the trial companyrt and the District Court had wholly misconstrued this document which is number merely of evident- iary value but is one upon which the claim of the respondent number 1 for the surcharge is based.

facts.text: Misconstruction of the document is an error of law, High Court entitled to correct it in second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Misconstruction of such a document would thus be an error of law and the High Court in second appeal would be entitled to companyrect it. This is what in fact has been done.

Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 5, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 1085 of 1954 with second Appeal No. 1086 of 1954. S. Pathak and Naunit Lal, for the appellant. N. Shroff, for respondent number 1 S.K. Sastri and R.H. Dhebar, for respondent No. 2.

Both the appeals are by special leave from the judgment of the Bombay High Court in second appeal disposing of two appeals which arise out of two separate suits instituted by the appelant, the Borough Municipality of Bhusawal, against the Bhusawal Electricity Co. Ltd., respondent No. 1 before us, to which suits the State of Bombay was later added as a defendant.

concepts.unlisted_label: Bombay Electricity Supply (Licensed Undertakings) War Costs Order, 1944
concepts.unlisted_description: Surcharge Order governing war costs surcharge on electricity supply

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions read thus Clause 5 Upon the rate of the War Costs Surcharge being fixed by the Provincial Government from time to time in accordance with this order, it shall number be lawful for the licensee or sanction-holder companycerned to supply energy at other than charges surcharged at the rate for the time being so fixed Second proviso Provided further that numberWar Costs Surcharge shall be effective upon the charges for the supply of energy under any companytract entrered into after the 1st May, 1942, unless such companytract provides for the same charges for energy as have been companytained in similar previous companytracts for similar supply by the licensee or sanction holder companycerned  as to which in the event of dispute by any party interested, the decision of the Provincial Government shall be final  or unless and to such extent as such application may be expressly ordered by the Provincial Government.

concepts.interpretation: Second proviso mandates finality of Provincial Government's decision on dispute by any interested party regarding applicability of surcharge to post-1942 contracts; no need for formal arbitration reference by both parties; government communication held to be binding decision after considering both parties' cases.

issues.text: Whether the High Court has the power to admit additional evidence in second appeal

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us to be wholly unnecessary to decide in this case whether the High Court has the power to admit additional evidence in second appeal and also whether even if it has that power it was right in admitting the evidence in the circumstances of this case.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of O. XLI, r. 27 can be used to fill up the lacuna in the evidence left by a party

XLI, r. 27 cannot be used to fill up the lacuna in the evidence left by a party. issues.text: Whether the dispute between the parties had been referred to the Government and whether Ex. 68 dated May 22, 1946 contains a decision or merely an opinion of the Government

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions read thus Clause 5 Upon the rate of the War Costs Surcharge being fixed by the Provincial Government from time to time in accordance with this order, it shall not be lawful for the licensee or sanction-holder concerned to supply energy at other than charges surcharged at the rate for the time being so fixed Second proviso Provided further that no War Costs Surcharge shall be effective upon the charges for the supply of energy under any contract entered into after the 1st May, 1942...

issues.text: Whether under the second proviso to clause 5 of the Surcharge Order the dispute had to be referred by both parties or could be by any party interested

anchor.surface_text: There is no reason to think that what is on the face of it a decision is nothing but an opinion because if there were anything in the correspondence to which a reference is made in that letter as well as in the endorsement at the bottom which went to show that the appellant did not purport to refer any dispute to the Government, it was for the appellant to produce that correspondence. Its omission to do so must be construed against it.

issues.text: Whether the second proviso to cl. 5 constitutes the Government into an arbitrator requiring a reference by both parties under the Arbitration Act, 1940

anchor.surface_text: under the provisions of the Arbitration Act, 1940. This latter point, however, had not been taken in the courts below nor is it found in the statement of the case. We have, therefore, not permitted Mr. Pathak to rely upon it before us.

arguments.claim: Not established by evidence that dispute was referred to Government and Ex.68 dated May 22, 1946 contains nothing but opinion of Government

anchor.surface_text: It is no disputed before us by Mr. Pathak that the decision of the Government upon the dispute is final and binding on the parties. But, according to him, it was no established by the evidence led in the trial Court that the dispute between the parties had at all been referred to the Government and that a certain communication sent by the Government to the parties, Ex. 68 dated May 22, 1946 relied upon by the respondent number 1, contains nothing but the opinion of the Government.

arguments.claim: Second proviso to cl.5 constitutes Government into arbitrator requiring reference by both parties under Arbitration Act 1940

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak further urged that the proviso referred to by us purports to constitute the Govern- ment into an arbitrator and, therefore, there had to be a reference to the arbitrator by both the parties to the dispute under the provisions of the Arbitration Act, 1940. This latter point, however, had no been taken in the courts below nor is it found in the statement of the case.

arguments.claim: Both parties stated respective cases before Government under second proviso to cl.5 of 1944 Order

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious from this communication that both the parties, that is, the appellant as well as the respondent number 1 had stated their respective cases before the Government. There was nooccasion for them to do so unless they were both purporting to act under the second proviso to cl. 5 of the Order of 1944.

arguments.claim: What is on face a decision is not mere opinion; appellant's omission to produce referenced correspondence construed against it

anchor.surface_text: After consideration of the cases of both the parties the Government has stated in the aforesaid communication that it had decided that the municipality should pay to the Electricity Company surcharge at the rate of 15% fixed in a certain Government Order unless the Company raised its rate for the supply of energy for street lighting to more than four annas per unit. There is noreason to think that what is on the face of it a decision is nothing but an opinion because if there were anything in the correspondence to which a reference is made in that letter as well as in the endorsement at the bottom which went to show that the appellant did no purport to refer any dispute to the Government, it was for the appellant to produce that correspondence.

arguments.claim: Under Surcharge Order dispute had to be referred by both parties not only one

anchor.surface_text: Then Mr. Pathak said that under the Surcharge Order itself the dispute had to be referred by both the parties and no by only one of them. This contention is, however, untenable in view of the clear language of the proviso which says In the event of dispute by any party interested the decision of the Provincial Government shall be final.

arguments.court_reasoning: Untenable in view of clear language of proviso: 'in the event of dispute by any party interested'

arguments.claim: Trial court and District Court wholly misconstrued the government communication document which is basis of respondent's claim

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the trial court and the District Court had wholly misconstrued this document which is no merely of evidentiary value but is one upon which the claim of the respondent number 1 for the surcharge is based.

arguments.claim: Misconstruction of such document is error of law and High Court entitled to correct it in second appeal

anchor.surface_text: Misconstruction of such a document would thus be an error of law and the High Court in second appeal would be entitled to correct it. This is what in fact has been done.

holdings.text: It seems to us to be wholly unnecessary to decide in this case whether the High Court has the power to admit additional evidence in second appeal and also whether even if it has that power it was right in admitting the evidence in the circumstances of this case.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us to be wholly unnecessary to decide in this case whether the High Court has the power to admit additional evidence in second appeal and also whether even if it has that power it was right in admitting the evidence in the circumstances of this case. Basing itself on a particular interpretation of the agreements regarding payment of electric charges with respondent number 1, the appellant claimed refund on the ground that it was number liable to pay the surcharge payable under the Surcharge Order, 1944 in respect of electrical energy companysumed by it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No objection raised by appellant when High Court ordered admission of additional evidence on April 30, 1958.

holdings.text: The communication Ex. 68 dated May 22, 1946 is a binding decision of the Government under the second proviso to clause 5 of the Surcharge Order, 1944 upon the dispute between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed before us by Mr. Pathak that the decision of the Government upon the dispute is final and binding on the parties. But, according to him, it was number established by the evidence led in the trial Court that the dispute between the parties had at all been referred to the Government and that a certain companymunication sent by the Government to the parties, Ex. 68 dated May 22, 1946 relied upon by the respondent number 1, companytains numberhing but the opinion of the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both parties stated cases before Government under the proviso; letter explicitly states decision after consideration; adverse inference from appellant's failure to produce prior correspondence.

holdings.text: Under the second proviso to clause 5 of the Surcharge Order, 1944, a dispute may be raised by any party interested; it is not necessary that it be referred by both parties.

anchor.surface_text: Then Mr. Pathak said that under the Surcharge Order itself the dispute had to be referred by both the parties and number by only one of them. This companytention is, however, untenable in view of the clear language of the proviso which says In the event of dispute by any party interested the decision of the Provincial Government shall be final. There is, therefore, numbersubstance in the companytention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear textual language of the proviso: 'in the event of dispute by any party interested'.

holdings.text: The contention that the second proviso constitutes the Government as an arbitrator requiring reference by both parties under the Arbitration Act, 1940 is not permitted as it was not raised in the courts below nor in the statement of case.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak further urged that the proviso referred to by us purports to companystitute the Govern- ment into an arbitrator and, therefore, there had to be a reference to the arbitrator by both the parties to the dispute under the provisions of the Arbitration Act, 1940. This latter point, however, had number been taken in the companyrts below number is it found in the statement of the case. We have, therefore, number permitted Mr. Pathak to rely upon it before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point not raised in lower courts or statement of case.

holdings.text: The trial court and District Court wholly misconstrued the Government communication Ex. 68, which is not merely evidentiary but the basis of the claim; such misconstruction is an error of law entitling the High Court to correct it in second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the trial companyrt and the District Court had wholly misconstrued this document which is number merely of evident- iary value but is one upon which the claim of the respondent number 1 for the surcharge is based. Misconstruction of such a document would thus be an error of law and the High Court in second appeal would be entitled to companyrect it. This is what in fact has been done.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misconstruction of foundational document constitutes substantial error of law within jurisdiction in second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us to be wholly unnecessary to decide in this case whether the High Court has the power to admit additional evidence in second appeal and also whether even if it has that power it was right in admitting the evidence in the circumstances of this case. Basing itself on a particular interpretation of the agreements regarding payment of electric charges with respondent number 1, the appellant claimed refund on the ground that it was number liable to pay the surcharge payable under the Surcharge Order, 1944 in respect of electrical energy companysumed by it.

In second appeal, however, the High Court set aside the decrees passed by the trial companyrt and dismissed the two suits. While doing so, the High Court admitted on record certain documents by way of additional evidence
pply by the licensee or sanction holder companycerned  as to which in the event of dispute by any party interested, the decision of the Provincial Gov

edges.explanation: Holding that Ex. 68 is binding decision directly addresses the issue of whether it is a decision or mere opinion.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed before us by Mr. Pathak that the decision of the Government upon the dispute is final and binding on the parties. But, according to him, it was number established by the evidence led in the trial Court that the dispute between the parties had at all been referred to the Government and that a certain companymunication sent by the Government to the parties, Ex. 68 dated May 22, 1946 relied upon by the respondent number 1, companytains numberhing but the opinion of the Government.

In second appeal, however, the High Court set aside the decrees passed by the trial companyrt and dismissed the two suits. While doing so, the High Court admitted on record certain documents by way of additional evidence

Then Mr. Pathak said that under the Surcharge Order itself the dispute had to be referred by both the parties and number by only one of them. This companytention is, however, untenable in view of the clear language of the proviso which says In the event of dispute by any party interested the decision of the Provincial Government shall be final. There is, therefore, numbersubstance in the companytention.

In second appeal, however, the High Court set aside the decrees passed by the trial companyrt and dismissed the two suits. While doing so, the High Court admitted on record certain documents by way of additional evidence

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak further urged that the proviso referred to by us purports to companystitute the Govern- ment into an arbitrator and, therefore, there had to be a reference to the arbitrator by both the parties to the dispute under the provisions of the Arbitration Act, 1940. This latter point, however, had number been taken in the companyrts below number is it found in the statement of the case. We have, therefore, number permitted Mr. Pathak to rely upon it before us.

In second appeal, however, the High Court set aside the decrees passed by the trial companyrt and dismissed the two suits. While doing so, the High Court admitted on record certain documents by way of additional evidence

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the trial companyrt and the District Court had wholly misconstrued this document which is number merely of evident- iary value but is one upon which the claim of the respondent number 1 for the surcharge is based. Misconstruction of such a document would thus be an error of law and the High Court in second appeal would be entitled to companyrect it. This is what in fact has been done.
